summary: A letter from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York to the Office of the Chief Medical Examiner (OCME) requesting that OCME withhold from disclosure certain materials related to the autopsy and investigation of Jeffrey Epstein's death, citing an ongoing criminal investigation into his suicide at the Metropolitan Correctional Center.

persons.name: Geoffrey S. Berman
persons.context: Signatory of the letter requesting the Office of the Chief Medical Examiner to withhold materials related to Jeffrey Epstein's autopsy and death investigation from third-party disclosure.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The individual whose death by suicide at the Metropolitan Correctional Center on August 10, 2019, is the subject of the ongoing criminal investigation and autopsy discussed in the document.

events.title: Jeffrey Epstein's Suicide at MCC
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein died by suicide at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC).

events.title: Information Sharing with OCME
events.description: The USAO and FBI provided the Office of the Chief Medical Examiner (OCME) with access to materials and information from their criminal investigation to assist in determining the cause and manner of Epstein's death.

locations: Silvio M. J. Mob Building, New York, New York 10007
Office of the Chief Medical Examiner, 421 East 26th Street, New York, New York
keyFacts: The U.S. Attorney's Office and FBI are conducting an ongoing criminal investigation into the events related to Jeffrey Epstein's suicide on August 10, 2019.
The Office of the Chief Medical Examiner (OCME) completed an autopsy of Jeffrey Epstein, but the criminal investigation remains ongoing.

The letter formally requests OCME to withhold from any third-party disclosure all documents, evidence, or information provided by the USAO or FBI, including materials from the MCC and interviews with federal law enforcement personnel.
The document indicates coordination between the criminal investigation and the medical examiner's office, with the former seeking to control the release of sensitive investigative information.
